StringWithMarkup.String: 2,2',6,6'-Tetrabromobisphenol A's production and use as a reactive flame retardant in epoxy and polycarbonate resins and additive flame retardant in acrylonitrile-butadiene-styrene (ABS) resins(1) may result in its release to the environment through various waste streams(SRC). Its primary use is as a reactive flame retardant in epoxy resin circuit boards and in electronic enclosures made of ABS resins(2). Production of the compound, product manufacturing, e-waste recycling, and wastewater treatment plants have been identified as the main emission point sources of 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A(3). A review of 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A in China has reported the compound to be a ubiquitous environmental contaminant that is observed in both abiotic and biotic matrices(4).[(1) O'Neil MJ, ed; The Merck Index. 15th ed., Cambridge, UK: Royal Society of Chemistry, p. 1703 (2013) (2) NIEHS; Tetrabromobisphenol A

StringWithMarkup.String: TERRESTRIAL FATE: Based on a classification scheme(1), an estimated Koc value of 2.7X10+5(SRC), determined from a structure estimation method(2), indicates that 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A is expected to be immobile in soil(SRC). The pKa1 and pKa2 of 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A are 7.5 and 8.5 respectively(3), indicating that this compound will exist partially in anion form in the environment and anions generally do not adsorb more strongly to soils containing organic carbon and clay than their neutral counterparts(4). Volatilization of 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A from moist soil surfaces is not expected to be an important fate process(SRC) given an estimated Henry's Law constant of 2.0X10-7 atm-cu m/mole(SRC), derived from its vapor pressure, 4.68X10-8 mm Hg(5), and water solubility, 0.171 mg/L(6). 2,2',6,6'-Tetrabromobisphenol A is not expected to volatilize from dry soil surfaces based upon its vapor pressure(SRC). Anaerobic biodegradation of 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A has been shown to occur in soil and sediment studies with primary degradation being nearly complete within 10-64 days in some tests(7-9). Anaerobic biodegradation occurs through a biodehalogenation through tri- and dibromobisphenol A with a final product of bisphenol A(8,9). Aerobic biodegradation in soil can also occur(10,11). Aerobic degradation in a Chinese sandy soil under static incubation for 143 days resulted in a half-life of 14.7 days(10). Other studies in aerobic soils have reported half-lives ranging from 9 to 93 days(11). Results of aqueous photolysis studies(12) suggest that direct photolysis may occur on soil surfaces exposed to sunlight(SRC).

StringWithMarkup.String: AQUATIC FATE: Based on a classification scheme(1), an estimated Koc value of 2.7X10+5(SRC), determined from a structure estimation method(2), indicates that 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A is expected to adsorb to suspended solids and sediment(SRC). Volatilization from water surfaces is not expected(3) based upon an estimated Henry's Law constant of 2.0X10-8 atm-cu m/mole(SRC), derived from its vapor pressure, 4.68X10-8 mm Hg(4) and water solubility, 0.171 mg/L(5). According to a classification scheme(6), BCF values ranging from 30 to 485(7,8) suggest the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is moderate to high. Anaerobic biodegradation of 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A has been shown to occur in sediment studies with primary degradation being nearly complete within 55 days(9) and 80% degradation in 10 days of incubation(10). Other studies in anaerobic sediments have reported half-lives ranging from 5 to >130 days(11). Anaerobic biodegradation occurs through a biodehalogenation through tri- and dibromobisphenol A with a final product of bisphenol A(9-11). Aerobic biodegradation may also occur based on a sediment/water study reporting half-lives from 48 to 84 days(12). Phototransformation studies of 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A in aqueous solution determined a UV absorption maximum at 310 nm, a quantum yield of 0.042 and decomposition rates ranging from 3.3X10-5 (at pH 5.5) to 6.8X10-4 (at pH 9) per second which correspond to a half-life range 17 minutes to 5.8 hours(13). 2,2',6,6'-Tetrabromobisphenol A is not expected to undergo hydrolysis in the environment due to the lack of functional groups that hydrolyze under environmental conditions(3). Phenols can undergo sensitized photo-oxidation in surface waters exposed to sunlight via reaction with hydroxyl (OH), peroxy (RO2) radicals and singlet oxygen with a half-live on the order of weeks at the water surface(14); therefore, photo-oxidation may have some importance as a fate process for 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A in natural water(SRC).

(4) Eriksson J et al; Chemosphere 54: 117-126 (2004)

StringWithMarkup.String: ATMOSPHERIC FATE: According to a model of gas/particle partitioning of semivolatile organic compounds in the atmosphere(1), 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A, which has a vapor pressure of 4.68X10-8 mm Hg at 25 °C(2), will exist in both the vapor and particulate phases in the ambient atmosphere. Vapor-phase 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A is degraded in the atmosphere by reaction with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals(SRC); the half-life for this reaction in air is estimated to be 5.4 days(SRC), calculated from its rate constant of 3.0X10-12 cu cm/molecule-sec at 25 °C(SRC) that was derived using a structure estimation method(3). Particulate-phase 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A may be removed from the air by wet and dry deposition(SRC). 2,2',6,6'-Tetrabromobisphenol A absorbs UV light at wavelengths >290 and is susceptible to direct photolysis by sunlight(4).

Section.Description: This section provides information on environmental biodegradation for this compound. Biodegradation is the breakdown of organic matter by microorganisms, such as bacteria and fungi.  An important measure of biodegradability of wastewater is the biochemical oxygen demand (BOD), which is the amount of dissolved oxygen (DO) needed (i.e. demanded) by aerobic biological organisms to break down organic material present in a given water sample at certain temperature over a specific time period.

StringWithMarkup.String: AEROBIC: 2,2',6,6'-Tetrabromobisphenol A, present at 100 mg/L, reached 0% of its theoretical BOD in 14 days using an activated sludge inoculum at 30 mg/L in the Japanese MITI test(1). Half-lives ranging from 48 to 84 days were measured for 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A in a natural river sediment/water study(2). Less than 8% of the applied radioactivity was recovered as CO2 during this study(2). After 56 days, 44.7%, 64.2% and 60.8% of 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A remained for initial concentrations of 10, 100, and 1000 ug/L, respectively(2). In aerobic degradation studies using microbial communities from river sediment from southern Taiwan found 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A half-lives ranging from 9.9 to 13.1 days at initial sediment concentrations of 50 ug/g(3); Bacillus pumilus and Rhodococcus ruber were the dominant bacteria in the degradation(3). The degradation of radio-labeled 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A in a Chinese sandy soil under static oxic incubation for 143 days resulted in a half-life of 14.7 days(4). Other studies in oxic soils have reported half-lives ranging from 9 to 93 days(5).

Reference: (1) Great Lakes Chem Corp; Determination of the Biodegradability of Tetrabromobisphenol A in Soil Under Anaerobic Conditions; 2/6/89; EPA Document No. 40-8998097; Fiche No. OTS0525513
(2) Voordeckers JW et al; Environ Sci Technol 36: 696-701 (2002)
(3) Ronen Z, Abeliovich A; Applied Environ Microbiol 66: 2372-2377 (2000)
(4) Liu J et al; Environ Sci Technol 47: 8348-8354 (2013)

StringWithMarkup.String: ANAEROBIC: 2,2',6,6'-Tetrabromobisphenol A at 10 mg/kg soil was incubated in 3 different soil samples under anaerobic conditions; only 0.35, 0.10, and 0.03% of the initially applied radioactivity was recovered as CO2 in 64 days indicating that this compound is slowly mineralized(1). After 64 days, 43.7 to 57.0%, 53.4 to 65.0% and 89.5 to 90.6% of the parent was still present in the three soils suggesting that this compound may undergo primary degradation fairly quickly in some soils(1). The biodehalogenation of 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A was examined in anoxic estuarine sediment studies(2); near complete loss of 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A was observed within 55 days with the formation of bisphenol A and some 2,6-dibromobisphenol A(2). Using anaerobic sediment from a wet ephemeral desert stream bed contaminated with chemical industry waste, 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A was nearly 80% degraded within 10 days of incubation with an intermediate formation of tri- and dibrominated bisphenol A metabolites and a final formation of bisphenol A(3). The degradation of radio-labeled 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A in a Chinese rice paddy soil under static anoxic incubation for 195 days resulted in a half-life of 36 days yielding four metabolites (bisphenol A (BPA) and mono-, di-, and tribrominated BPA)(4). Other studies in anoxic sediments have reported half-lives ranging from 5 to >130 days(4).

StringWithMarkup.String: The rate constant for the vapor-phase reaction of 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals has been estimated as 3.0X10-12 cu cm/molecule-sec at 25 °C(SRC) using a structure estimation method(1). This corresponds to an atmospheric half-life of about 5.4 days at an atmospheric concentration of 5X10+5 hydroxyl radicals per cu cm(1). A theoretical vapor-phase OH radical rate constant of 1.02X10-12 cu cm/molecule-sec has been estimated for 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A based on quantum thermodynamic approximations(2). 2,2',6,6'-Tetrabromobisphenol A absorbs UV light at wavelengths >290 and is susceptible to direct photolysis by sunlight(3). Phototransformation studies of 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A in aqueous solution determined a UV absorption maximum at 310 nm, a quantum yield of 0.042 and decomposition rates ranging from 3.3X10-5 (at pH 5.5) to 6.8X10-4 (at pH 9) per second which correspond to a half-life range of 17 minutes to 5.8 hours(3). 2,2',6,6'-Tetrabromobisphenol A is not expected to undergo hydrolysis in the environment due to the lack of functional groups that hydrolyze under environmental conditions(4). Phenols can undergo sensitized photo-oxidation in surface waters exposed to sunlight via reaction with hydroxyl (OH), peroxy (RO2) radicals and singlet oxygen with a half-live on the order of weeks at the water surface(5); therefore, photo-oxidation may have some importance as a fate process for 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A in natural water(SRC). Irradiation studies in aqueous humic acid suspensions using wavelengths >300 nm identified the main photodecomposition byproducts as 2,6-dibromo-p-benzosemiquinone anions and tribromohydroxybisphenol A(6).

Section.Description: This section provides information on environmental bioconcentration for this compound.  Bioconcentration is the accumulation of a chemical in or on an organism when the source of chemical is solely water. Bioconcentration is a term that was created for use in the field of aquatic toxicology. Bioconcentration can also be defined as the process by which a chemical concentration in an aquatic organism exceeds that in water as a result of exposure to a waterborne chemical.

Reference: (1) NITE; Chemical Risk Information Platform (CHRIP). Biodegradation and Bioconcentration. Tokyo, Japan: Natl Inst Tech Eval. Available from, as of April 10, 2018: https://www.safe.nite.go.jp/english/db.html

StringWithMarkup.String: BCF ranges of 30 to 341 and 52 to 485 were measured for 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A using carp (Cyprinus carpio) which were exposed over an 8-week period to concentrations of 80 and 8 ug/L, respectively(1). A BCF value of 307 was measured in fathead minnow (Pimepahles promelas)(2). According to a classification scheme(3), these BCF values suggest the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is moderate to high.

Section.Description: Sorption to soils and sediments is an important factor on the transport and fate of organic contaminants in the environment.  The soil/water adsorption coefficient, also known as solid-water distribution coefficient (Kd), measures the amount of chemical substance adsorbed onto soil per amount of water.  Since adsorption occurs predominantly by partition into the soil organic matter, it is more useful to normalize the Kd value to the organic carbon content of a soil and express the distribution coefficient in Koc (organic carbon normalized distribution coefficient).  The greater the Kd (or Koc) value, the less likely a chemical will leach or contribute to runoff.  A very high value means it is strongly adsorbed onto soil and organic matter and does not move throughout the soil.

StringWithMarkup.String: Using a structure estimation method based on molecular connectivity indices(1), the Koc for 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A can be estimated to be 2.7X10+5(SRC). According to a classification scheme(2), this estimated Koc value suggests that 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A is expected to be immobile in soil. The pKa1 and pKa2 of 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A are 7.5 and 8.5 respectively(3), indicating that this compound will exist partially in anion form in the environment and anions generally do not adsorb more strongly to soils containing organic carbon and clay than their neutral counterparts(4). Soil column and batch adsorption studies using loam soil and sand found  2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A is sorbed extensively by both soil and sand(5).

StringWithMarkup.String: SURFACE WATER: In 12 water samples collected from Taihu Lake, China (the third largest freshwater lake in China that is surrounded by highly developed cities and towns) in Sept 2010, 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A was detected in 3 samples at concentrations of 1.12, 0.45 and 0.36 ng/L(1). A 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A concentration range of 850-4870 ng/L was detected in Lake Chaohu(2). English lake waters had a concentration range of 0.14-3.2 ng/L in 27 samples(3). A median 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A concentration of 68 pg/L was detected in pooled water (3 samples) collected from the Pearl River Delta, South China between 2005 and 2008(5).

StringWithMarkup.String: SEDIMENT: River sediment collected from the Neya River, Japan, in September 1981 contained approximately 20 ug/kg on a dry weight basis of 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A(1). Marine sediments collected from estuaries in Japan other than from Osaka Bay contained 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A at concentrations of <0.5 ppb to 1.8 ppb, dry weight basis(2). Marine sediments collected from estuaries in Osaka Bay contained 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A at 0.5 to 4.5 ppb while river sediments collected in Osaka contained this compound at concentrations from 22 to 140 ppb(2). Sediment samples collected in Arkansas contained unreported concentrations of 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A(3). Sediment samples upstream and downstream from a plastics plant contained 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A concentrations of 50 and 430 ng/g respectively(4). A sediment sample from the Tromso harbor (Northern Norway) contained a 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A concentration of 1.24 ng/g dry wt(5). Sediment samples collected downstream at varying distances from a factory in Hunan, China in 2010 had 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A concentrations ranging from about 140 to <5 ng/g dry wt (distances 0.5 to 7.7 km) with levels decreasing as distance from the factory increased(6). In 12 sediment samples collected from Taihu Lake, China (the third largest freshwater lake in China that is surrounded by highly developed cities and towns) in Sept 2010, 2,2',6,6'-tetrabromobisphenol A was detected at a concentration range of 0.056-2.15 ng/g dry wt(7). English lake sediments (9 samples) had a reported concentration range of 0.33-3.8 ng/g dry wt(8).

StringWithMarkup.String: 2,2',6,6'-Tetrabromobisphenol A concentrations varying from 0.06 to 37.34 ng/g were detected in breast milk samples collected from 93 volunteers in France between 2004 and 2006(1); 44% of all samples collected contained detectable levels(1). Breast milk samples collected from 10 volunteers in Birmingham, UK during 12 months of lactation (2010 to 2011) had a detection frequency of 61% with concentrations of 0.03-0.17 ng/g lipid wt (5th to 95th percentile) and an average concentration of 0.06 ng/g(2). A few studies demonstrate the presence of TBBPA in breast milk, with average levels between 0.06 and 4.11 ng/g fat, suggesting that milk represents a substantial route of excretion for TBBPA in humans(3).

Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.
